Things we learned after successfully delivering and launching 12+ AI products 👇🏻

1/ There are way more use cases of AI than building a simple chatbot 🤖 Think outside the box. People are tired of chatbots.

2/ AI is a feature, and it shouldn't be your key selling point anymore 💸 Everyone has jumped into AI and your product really has to solve a problem to survive

3/ The barrier to entry is almost non-existent. The only limitation is your laziness to get started 💤

4/ You can solve a problem really well if you have faced that yourself. If you are looking for ideas, get yourself in situations where you can encounter problems ⛑️

5/ Boring ideas are the best. Use AI to solve problems of boring businesses and you have a profitable product 💡

6/ Your AI product should not take months and months to launch. AI is rapidly changing and if your product is not out in the open soon enough, it might face the fate of dinosaurs 🦖 🎇

We've built AI products used by thousands daily (developed in weeks!), and some that flopped (developed in months). The difference? Execution ✨

I took this as a weekend challenge, explored Hugging Face, and built some Colab Notebooks and Streamlit apps to analyze the performance of LLMs like Llama3 & Jais. And everything worked great.

In the first year of, I was very much hands-on with engineering. But with the team expanding and new business challenges coming up every other day, it became too hard for me to code myself.

Even though I love it. I love to code, build things, and architect the solutions as a piece of engineering art. But I can't focus too much on it. I can give my input on different projects, help out with some technical decisions, but I can't be very much hands on. If I do, the business might struggle.

So a couple of weeks ago, a client reached out. They needed help with something that I had never worked on myself. Though our team had worked on such things a lot, so I knew if I failed, our "rockstar engineers" would jump in to help this "rusty engineer" out.

Spent some days on it, spent the weekend, and.... you can see what the client says in the picture below👇🏻

So maybe..... I am not that rusty..... yet!

Mission ✅

People are loving Track your Subs 🎉

We launched Track your Subs almost 1 month ago and seems like we really solved an actual pain point of some people.

Within just one month, we have released some major updates to the app like:

💹 Improved stats
🌎 Multi-currency support
🏷️ Labeling and categorization (should be live within next few hours 👀)
✨ Bunch of UI improvements and enhancements

We are serving 140+ registered users and 700+ users in total, most of them from the US. We heard the feedback of users and implemented most of the features that people requested.

If you still haven't given it a try, go check us out (and leave us a review 👀) and let us know if you have any feedback.

Download Now ->

These past one and a half years have been crazy for tech 👇🏻

- OpenAI, a company no one had heard of, became the most popular tech company in the world
- Every other company tried to follow suit and launch their own AI
-crossed $3 trillion market cap because of this AI mania
- Some of the biggest names in tech fell behind in the AI race

&

finally, yesterday,announced Apple Intelligence (AI). Making AI even more mainstream by integrating AI features in all of their product line up.

If you think AI was overhyped, get ready to be bombarded by even more AI startups, and AI products coming up after this announcement.

Some bold and unconventional bets I took while building RipeSeed 👇🏻

1 - Adding our engineers directly to our Upwork agency, with their own personal profiles (not company-owned). They are free to take their profiles with them if they choose to leave.

2 - Not calling ourselves a "US-based" company. Neither on our Upwork, our website, or our social profiles. We proudly own and operate as a Pakistan-based 🇵🇰 software company.

3 - Hiring our engineers on contracts with their own profiles, not just with my profile, hence resulting in many Top Rated Plus Profiles on our Upwork agency account.

4 - Not faking our team's capabilities. Not shadowing junior engineers with the names of senior engineers. Even if that means losing a potential customer. If we can't do something, we communicate that clearly.

5 - Not hiring interns (SEs) to cut costs. Instead, we always hired engineers who had prior experience in full-stack development. As an early-stage company, we can't afford to invest our time in training engineering interns.

All these steps are very unconventional and considered risky in the agency business. And I'd be lying if I said I wasn't afraid of them. But I was willing to either not grow at all, or grow on the right terms. And I think it worked out decently well for us.

I just COULD NOT live an “automatic” life...

Back in my college days, when people were just focused on passing their exam to get into a good university, I could have gone with the flow and just focused on my curriculum. But I ended up watching the whole playlist ofbyand learnt C++. My first step into programming.

And then finally after getting into,, the university I wanted to get in, I could have just gone with the flow, followed the defined path and enjoyed the university life. But I ended up doing freelancing, working on more real world projects before graduation than most people do in their first four years of career.

And then after graduating, I could have just lived and enjoyed my life on the nice paychecks I was getting from my jobs. But I continued doing freelancing alongwith all my jobs, making my nights harder and sleepless, while still working honestly and fulltime in my day job.

And then I could have just continued doing jobs, switching from one company to the other. But I ended up starting, building a team, with no business experience, no funding or bootstrap money. Taking the constant headache, stress and worry of what the next day is going to be.

And then finally.... I mean finally... I could have just taken the easy way out to build the business, shadowing people by faking their experience/names/profiles, but I opted to stay honest to our customers. Showing our capabilities for who we actually are and what we can actually do. The path usually not taken by initial stage companies (or even some mature ones as well)

And I am so thankful for all of it. I don't think all of it can be categorized as hardwork. Alot of it is luck and prayers. Many things have to go right for all of it to result in a positive outcome. But I am so glad I could not live the life on auto-mode. And I hope it stay that way.

Track your Subs users just received this notification 🔔 

It's a public apology, because we know hundreds of our users are now relying on us to keep track of their expenses. We know we messed up and we know we need to announce this so people can update their apps and keep enjoying the seemless experience.

We would've never caught this bug if we weren't using the app ourselves. Track your Subs solves an actual pain point of the people who are subscribed to a bit too many subscription service, for better or for worse.

We have received an amazing response from people, a lot of downloads and people actively using the app to keep track of their expenses. Looking forward to serving more users and super excited for the next set of features we are working on based on the feedback we have received.

The tiredness, the pain, the tough times, and the sleepless nights will go away. And when it’s gone, all that’s left will be the reward you gained from those efforts.

I unlocked this life hack a few years ago. It’s more of a realization than a life hack.

The hardship is temporary. The reward is long-lasting.

Feeling really tired because of a project or a client?
↳ Just get it done and get it over with. When it's done, you'll be able to rest, the customer will be happy, and you'll be left with a good testimonial and a happy customer

"It's weekend and I still have to work. What about work-life balance? What about personal time? Why did I commit to something like this?"
↳ Just do it and deliver what you promised. You know you took this challenge to upskill yourself. Why back off now? When it's done, you'll have learned something you always wanted to learn and there will be plenty of weekends to enjoy.

I have had situations like these where I thought I should just get out of the tough situation by taking an easy way out. By giving up the challenge. By refunding the client. By giving up the project. But this thought, that when all of this ends, I'll be left with a reward that'll stay longer, unlike the tiredness and burnout that can be cured with a good night's sleep.

So .... keep going.

Hard to swallow pill: Things really work out, if you are willing to put in the work.

There's no way around it. You cannot outsource it. You cannot delegate it.

You can procrastinate if you want to, and you'll have to pay the price for it, but things will never figure themselves out.

And I have seen this happen a lot in the past few months.

1. I was worried about losing some recently closed clients. "What are we doing wrong?" And it happened a few times before but I never thought much about it. I was confident we'd close more. But I am glad that pride was shattered and I got to look deeper into the problem. And just because I spent time looking into the problem, I figured it was about relationship management and better customer experience. We worked towards perfecting these two things and we improved a lot.

2. Sales were really slowing down, number of leads generated and closed was going down as well, and I decided to just spend 2-4 hours every week with the sales team to look into the issues. Turned out that our outreach had a lot of room for improvement. I did my best to guide our sales team and our numbers finally increased.

3. Everyone wants to build a good public image of their brand. But only very few people are willing to put in the work. I spent a lot of time rethinking our social media strategy, thinking about what we could do to stand out. Now, all the carefully crafted content you see on's profile and website is a result of that thought process and spending many hours per week, thinking about what more we can do.

4. My team has delivered some amazingly complex projects with AI & machine learning. But I was always reluctant to get into it myself. I was a hardcore developer. And somehow, AI became a black box for me. I never spent much time looking into it, assuming that it's beyond me. Until last week. A client reached out with a project where they needed help with some Arabic LLMs. I don't know what got into me, but I decided to take on the challenge myself, spent the weekend cursing myself why I took on the challenge (we all do, right? right?), and finally delivered what the client needed. And now, it's not a black box anymore.

Amazing isn't it? Who could've thought that just putting in the work ..... actually works out!

After a successful launch and amazing feedback from people, we released a huge update for Track your Subs 💵 yesterday. Here's the thought process that went behind that release:

💰 People don't always have their subscriptions in the same currency. Their local apps & mobile data charges are usually in their local currency. So having support for multiple currencies is a must. I brainstormed withand we came up with an approach. So we added support for 100+ currencies in this release

☁️ We got hundreds of downloads 🤯 but people weren't signing up 🤕 I asked myself, why? We clearly have a "Login" button on top of the app. Turns out, users didn't know why they should sign up. What do they get out of it? What features are enabled by signing up? So we added a nice popup showing the user that they will be getting cloud syncing support and will be able to view/manage their portfolio across multiple devices

💹 One of the key reasons people will use Track your Subs, is that they wanna know at a glance what they are paying on a monthly basis. Our overview card was nice and simple but something seemed missing. So we revamped the whole card and nicely added the cumulative sums for both current and next month, so users know what to expect next month.

🧹 And of course, we needed to clean up some bugs and issues that the users reported and made the UI a bit more nicer and cleaner.

It's been so exciting working on TYS, listening to user's feedback, and implementing them accordingly. I'll try to keep posting about how it goes from an engineering + marketing standpoint as well.

So... if you still haven't.... then go Track your Subs 💵

People are afraid of directly engaging their customers with their employees because they are afraid that either their customer will hire their employees directly or their employees will steal away their clients. 

Never happened with us. Never. Once.

Since day one, we have engaged our team members directly with our customers.

The team gets to learn how to effectively communicate with a customer.

The customer feels like they are being given more transparency about what is being done and by whom.

A win-win for everyone.

So does that mean that the fear is totally unreasonable? No, I don't think so. Things like these happen. Never happened with us, but they do happen in the world.

And they happen because of the following reasons:

- Your team doesn't like working with you or your company. They might fear you, but they don't like you. Which is why they won't care if any of their actions hurt you or your business.
↳ Solution? Be likable. Work towards the interests of your team as well. Be approachable and make sure they feel comfortable enough to reach out to you whenever needed.

- Clients don't get any value out of working with you. You are just a middleman and you have invested exactly zero number of hours in establishing a relationship.
↳ Solution? Provide some value other than the manpower to your clients. Be the consultant who is working for them without charging anything extra. Provide your own consultancy as a complimentary service. They should work with your company because of you, not just because of the manpower you have.

In our lifetime (almost 3 years now), only two of our customers tried to directly hire our team members. And what then happened? In both cases, the team members reached out to us and told us that the customers were offering to hire them directly. And in both cases, the team members preferred staying with us.

I'll just call ourselves lucky, but there might be a pattern to this luck as well.

Go find your own pattern.

I genuinely feel like my team should grow. No strings attached. And every step we have ever taken, every policy we have ever made, has been around this one simple goal. 

1/ Even though we started with Upwork and our main client base has always been from Upwork, I never wanted to have the culture in my team where everyone is tracking their screens and logging each and every minute of their hands on the keyboard. We clearly communicate with our clients that if you really want to work with us, screen trackers are out of the question. And we have definitely lost a handful of opportunities because of that, but so what? We have a pool of good and decent clients who align with us on this mindset.

2/ In the first few months, when my team members were undergraduates and in their last semester, I clearly asked them to go ahead and apply for other companies. There's a certain fun attached to it. I didn't want to steal this from them. I told them to apply anywhere they want, and whatever offer the industry will be giving at that time, we'll offer more. And we did. And all three of those team members are still with us today. (so proud of it, I know I keep mentioning this in every other post)

3/ We had some really good team members leave us. My process is simple. I talk to them and see if the opportunity is better for them than working with us. And if it is, I encourage them to go ahead and explore the industry. Take on this new opportunity, grow themselves professionally and then come back to us as senior team members.

4/ I have gone as far as advising an interviewee once to go ahead and accept another remote company's offer. Not because he wasn't good, he was one of the most exceptionally talented one I ever interviewed. But as per his goals, that other opportunity was just way too good.

5/ I try to talk to every team member in 1-1 meetings. As a small company, this is our leverage. I get to personally connect to each and everyone, help them with their goals, and try to match our goals with theirs.

6/ I love guiding my team in their own personal projects, products, or issues they are facing with their clients. I have nothing to lose. And it's fun. If they are here helping me figure things out in RipeSeed, I should be there to help them figure out theirs as well. Right?

People keep asking me how we have been able to build such a great team, Alhamdulillah. And I think the answer lies somewhere over here. But I think if you genuinely work towards the success and goals of your team, your team will eventually work towards your success and will try and understand your pains as well.

Worked out pretty well for us.

Keeping your moral compass in check is critical in your personal and professional life. And we have rejected so many opportunities just because our moral compass didn't allow us to pursue them.

"𝐈'𝐥𝐥 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐲𝐨𝐮, 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦"

It's a phrase we have heard from the very early days and we still do. And that's fine. I respect that. Some people might not be willing to work with agencies and that's fine. All of the clients we have ever worked with knew who they were working with and we kept the team, the processes, and the faces always transparent.

I worked with a client in the early days to help him fix an urgent issue. He was really impressed. He told me he has other projects in the pipeline that he'd like to hire me for. I told him that even though I am the only person in the team right now, I'll later hire more people, and if someone is suitable, he'll be working on the project. That was a deal breaker for him. I tried to convince him but he didn't agree and I had to let him go.

Now I could use the excuse of being the only person in the team to hide the agency, but if I had crossed that line in the early days, that line would have vanished right then and there.

No one likes to lie. Even the people who do. But if you do it once, it becomes so much easier to do it the second time, and then the third, and by the fourth time, your moral compass is tuned to ignore it altogether.

"But... but... I am just starting out"
You won't be able to fix your ways if you start the wrong way. Let it start slow. Face the difficulties. You won't know what to fix if you keep ignoring the problem.

"But it's hard these days"
That's not an excuse to lie to your customers. If everyone starts lying, how do we know who to trust?

God knows we have said "No" to opportunities even in hard times and only God knows how (because I don't) we were always able to get out of the hard times.

The world becomes a much better place if all of us (or at least the majority) just keep our moral compass in check.

I was always reluctant to work on our products. I was afraid that like many other service-focused companies, we'd end up using these products as filler projects, and won't be able to launch them due to a lack of focus.

Or worse, we'll focus too much on them and our focus will divert from the revenue-generating part of the business (working with clients) to the non-revenue-generating part of the business.

But then, near the end of 2024, I metand saw the amazing work he was doing, launching his own products and running a profitable business out of it. That served as the first seed of motivation in me to focus on building something of our own. I started following more people on Twitter and LinkedIn and discovered,,, Bhanu Teja (pbteja1998 @ X), and a few more bootstrapped SaaS founders. They were building and shipping like crazy and some of their products skyrocketed.

So earlier this year when I posted about our achievements in 2023 and our goals for 2024, I mentioned that we'll finally start working on our products.

Now the problem was, what should we build? I was suddenly out of ideas and I could not think of anything meaningful. Wasted a month just writing and scrapping ideas on Notion.

Then I thought to myself, "Ok, I'll just develop the first thing that comes to my mind, just to get out of this mind-blocker"

The criteria was simple:
- Build something very simple
- It doesn't have to be world-changing
- Build something that can be released in 2 weeks

So the first idea was a recipe app. We built a simple recipe app and launched it, but we didn't announce its launch anywhere. Because the idea was a bit too basic. But that really served its purpose. It opened my mind to more ideas and the next one that came to my mind was:

Track your Subs 💵

We estimated 2 weeks for its development. But it was a bit more complex than we thought. Offline capability seemed crucial. We added a feature to track whether or not you have paid for it or not. But later we scraped that because we wanted to keep it really simple. Too many options make the apps harder to use. We added history, editing records and few more tiny features like these that make the overall experience really good and help keep track of your expenses. Our designers were also occupied with client projects, and those have the highest priority. All these factors contributed to the delay in release.

What was originally planned to take only 2 weeks, ended up taking 2 months.

Then finally yesterday, I publically announced the launch of Track your Subs. And we were overwhelmed by the response.

We got 30 signups, and of course, a feature crashed for some users. Spent a few hours last night releasing a hotfix with. We've got a lot of ideas and feature requests and we are now planning to release some exciting updates soon.

So... stay tuned!

We are (finally) launching our (kinda) first product 🎉

Track your Subs 💵

Android:
iOS:

Problem: With so many apps and services offering monthly subscriptions, a lot of us are surprised to see random messages like "$$$ has been charged on your card" and at that moment, it's already too late.

Solution: Track all your subscriptions in one place, have a look at your overall upcoming monthly expense, and get notified a few days before you are going to be charged, so you can go and unsubscribe if you need to.

There is a long story behind how we came up with this idea, why we decided to build a product of our own, and how we launched. I'll be posting more about it very soon here, but for now, go check it out and give us your honest and brutal feedback.

Credits:
- The muscle

Me - (Just) The brain

Stress is good for business—or at least, it proved good for me and RipeSeed.

November 2023 to January 2024 was the most stressful time for me, running RipeSeed. We were struggling to close new clients, some of the existing ones ramped down, and as the team size increased, for the first time ever, I started seeing that we might go negative (in revenue) if somehow we didn’t close new clients.

That stress made me do things that I had never done before.

1. I have always been pushing my team to explore more ways to generate leads, but if you are not good at something yourself (especially in the initial days), it’s really hard to make your team believe that it can work. So in these desperate times, I started engaging more and more on various social platforms, and luckily, to my surprise, I was able to schedule multiple calls and was able to build some good relations.

2. Unlike my usual self, I reached out to Sir, CEO of, a very well-reputed firm, one I am a fan of and I had the chance to work in, asking for mentorship and guidance. To my surprise, he agreed. I met him and discussed all the issues I was facing and the amount of value I got from him was immense. It really opened some doors in my mind.

3. After my meeting with him, I started reflecting on the topics we discussed, and I figured something out. I figured that I was worrying too much about increasing the outreach. Instead, I should have been more focused on the quality of outreach. And this revelation was the best thing I did for our sales early this year. I started conducting 1 hour+ sessions every week with the sales team to review the quality of outreach we were doing, and started giving them my feedback on their approach on a weekly basis. And we saw some amazing results because of this.

4. I reached out to some existing clients of ours and discussed the possibility of longer-term contracts, instead of one-off or ad-hoc engagements. And multiple clients of ours agreed to longer-term engagements.

If it wasn’t for this time of panic or stress, I might have never stepped out of my comfort zone and taken these steps to fix these issues.

*companies spending millions $$$ in marketing their half-baked, barely working AI products*

Zuck 👇🏻

I tested Mathematical capabilities of Meta AI. It failed initially but then performed remarkably well 💯

ChatGPT and other Gen AI models don't work great with Mathematical calculations. (I actually haven't tested ChatGPT with this in a while so can't say for sure what the current state is)

The problem:

"Calculating bill for engineering resources, based on the number of hours worked"

1/ Initially I only told Meta AI that we work 40 hours/week
2/ It calculated correctly for January, but for February, somehow it calculated a higher amount, even though it recognized that February could be 28 days
3/ I corrected it's mistake and it calculated a correct amount for next month

Then I provided more clarification:

"We actually work 8 hrs/day, from Monday to Friday only, recalculate the bill for each month according to work days"

And here it worked surprisingly well. It correctly calculated the cost for both months. But couldn't infer that this year is Leap. So I prompted accordingly and it readjusted the calculations.

Really surprised that it was able to do these calculations accurately. Will have to test a bit more to see how reliable Meta AI is for analytical queries, but this little experiment was 👌🏻

Ok so I played around with Meta AI on WhatsApp And.... it's pretty handy. 

✅ Asked to create images of people celebrating birthday (inspired by that Sora video) and it did decently well. Number of fingers seemed accurate. Asked to make changes in the images and result was still decent

🚫 Failed to generate images based on real people. Tried for Benedict Cumberbatch and Elon Musk

⏳Asked to generate images of kids playing in ground, result was good but facial features were pretty bad

🤷🏻‍♂️ Asked about value of BTC and whether or not halving has happened (it happened yesterday) and it didn't know about it. Admitted that it doesn't have real time knowledge of the internet.

✌🏻 Asked to generate a summary of Rich Dad Poor Dad and generate images of Rich and Poor dad as per the book. And even though I don't totally agree with the representation, it's not totally disappointing as well

and then finally....

🤞 Asked about myself just by my name "Tell me about Hashir Baig from Pakistan and everything he's doing" and it said it doesn't know any notable figure by that name.

👏🏼 Asked about, to which it gave a detailed description of everything we do. Then I asked about who's the founder and it gave me a generous intro about myself (now I can sleep peacefully)

Super fun so far. Let's see where it goes!

It was mid-Feb and an old client of ours reached out. They needed to build an MVP for a Health-tech app with a dedicated interface for Patients, Healthcare providers, and key stakeholders. It was the kind of project that every engineer wants to get their hands on and we got super excited to work on it.

I called(the Engineering Lead @ RipeSeed) to start the planning phase of the project and see how we can allocate resources to get this project delivered successfully and "on time". Time was the key here. We wanted to make sure that we were not overwhelmed by the huge scope.

So we started breaking down the features and defined smaller & achievable goals. The first goal was for 2 weeks, where we planned to deliver the patient app, that could allow the patients to input how they feel and point out where they feel the pain in their body in an interactive UI.&started working withto deliver this first phase. Near the end of 2nd week, we felt we might be exceeding the deadline a bit.

As much as I hate to have my team work overtime and on the weekends, we had a discussion with the team and they understood the nature of the project and deliverables and agreed to go the extra mile. We communicated with the client as well, that we might be a couple of days overdue on the deadline, they agreed and we finally delivered a functional Patient app to the client. This helped boost the morale of the team and we were on our way to the next phases of the app.

The team was keen on delivering a piece of art with this project, so we took more time than we originally estimated, just because we wanted to do things the right way, even if that meant we'd be off by a couple of days in the delivery. Of course, we kept the communication channel open with the customers and they appreciated that we were prioritizing good engineering over everything.

And then finally this month, we delivered the last phase of the project and handed off everything to the client side. The end product was done so well that every stakeholder on the client side appreciated the team's effort and was super happy. And below you can see how the whole team felt after the successful delivery of this project.

~

An 'opinion' should be unbiased. 

An 'opinion' should not be used as a tool to 'sell'. 

The sole purpose of an opinion should be to help the other side. Without having your own personal benefit. Or even if you do have your own benefit, make sure it's stated absolutely clearly.

Whenever someone asks you for an opinion or advice, they are asking for help on a matter they feel they don't have expertise in. If later they find out that your suggestions were biased, and you had your own hidden benefit in them, you'll lose your credibility for a lifetime.

And this happens a lot in consulting businesses. Customers are usually not aware of how to achieve their desired results. How to build something in a cost-effective manner, whether or not something should be pursued, given the time and budget constraints.

A consultant should always try to give unbiased opinions, even if that means losing or cutting down on the scope of work.

We don't hesitate to say:

"We might not be a right fit for such a project"
"This feature might seem simple from your perspective but it'll require significant amount of work. Are you sure we should do it?"

And clients always appreciate this input. As a consultant, your job is to work for the client's success. Not solely for your personal benefit. If all your opinions and all your advice boil down to increasing your own revenue numbers and achieving your own goals, you are playing a losing game.

It's not fun arguing with a customer. It's difficult to say "No we can't tolerate this". You risk losing them. But sometimes if you don't take a stand at the right time, you develop a toxic relationship with a client, which is very bad in the long run.

We were working with a customer over a year ago and I started noticing a change of tone in their messages. Their messages were aggressive and their behaviour with our engineers started feeling off. We were working with them for a few months already, so I knew there was longer-term potential, but if I didn't intervene then, the relationship was on its way to go downhill.

I messaged them privately and told them they can't talk like this with any of our team members. It's not something we do in our company and it kills the motivation of the engineers who are working hard on delivering a fine product. To my surprise, the customer responded saying they didn't mean to hurt anyone and they might have been harsh with their words, for which they do apologize. In a few minutes, they dropped a message in the group chat apologizing for a harsh tone.

After that day, they never turned aggressive and always gave their feedback in a respectful manner. We kept working for them for a few more months and the relationship was better than ever.

We faced a few more cases like these where I had to jump in and tell the customer that their behavior was not suitable, and luckily for us, in all scenarios, the engagement continued and we didn't lose the customer.

Times like these test you for who you really are. If you are going to have your team's back, or if you are going to do everything and anything to please the customers. And it's nearly impossible to build a strong culture, a trustworthy team, and a stable business if you don't stand up for yourself or your team.

The hardest part of building a "good" tech company, is building a good engineering team. And you cannot build a good engineering team if you don't love the engineering yourself. 

That is why unlike every other business, most of the successful tech companies are founded by engineers instead of businessmen. Ultimately those engineering-founders turn into businessmen, but the core of the business surrounds heavily around engineers. They are the raw product of a good tech company.

The company can have a vision, a plan, and goal to aim for, but if the raw material is not good, the end product is never going to be decent enough.

The Rise of LayoutLMs and using Document Understanding Models Instead of Conventional OCR Techniques.

Companies are sitting on a ton of data, shared across the organization in the form of documents. That can be contracts, invoices, bank statements, or identity documents. The conventional OCR techniques are not very useful for structured documents, as the structure itself conveys a lot of context, and conventional OCR is only able to extract text from the document.

To solve that problem, we now have models like DONUT and some cloud services like's Document AI and's Document Intelligence that can help us extract meaningful data from structured documents. These models extract the context of the data along with the content, which means parsing invoices or bank statements can result in structured responses having information about pricing, transactions, debitors, and creditors without us having to infer the meaning of the data on our own, like we used to with conventional OCR techniques.

Being honest in the business is not always going to be rewarding. And times like these test you for who you really are.

And I have faced my fair share of challenges with my strict “honesty policy”

- When we tell our clients that we are a small team that started just about three years ago, they don't always feel comfortable working with us. They might be looking for a bigger and mature company with many years of experience. And we have to let them go.

- When we tell the clients that we are a team based entirely in Pakistan, and they don't always get ready to work with us right away. Yeah we can get ourselves registered in US for a couple hundred dollars, but even then I'll stick to what we actually are. If we have to face some stereotypes, so be it.

- Clients don't always like working with agencies. Now we could tell them they can hire someone directly from us and hide a team of engineers behind the scenes, but that's strictly, morally and ethically wrong in my rule book and I've declined so many clients just because of that.

- Clients don't always appreciate that we are a young team of super passionate engineers. Sometimes they are looking for 6-10 Years of experience and we have to respectfully let them go. Lying to them about something we don't have, is a no-go in my rule book

- Sometimes clients are looking for some prior experience, and if we don't have that, we have a strict policy to communicate about what we know and what we don't. “We feel like we can definitely help you out with it, but if you are looking for experience, we might not be the right choice”


People don't believe this when I tell them that's how we operate. But go ask anyone at, go ask any of our clients and you'll know the truth.

And ever after saying “no” to so many clients, to so many opportunities, we were about to grow to a team of 28 people in the short span of almost 3 years. And I am happy with the progress.

Getting started with AI is extremely easy in 2024. The only barrier to entry is your own imagination of what you can do with it.

AI didn't take our job. It actually helped us keep our job and create more in 2023, and it's doing the same in 2024. 

ChatGPT launched near the very end of 2022, and till then, our skillset, as a company, was mostly in Full Stack Web and Mobile apps development, our team was mostly working on existing products of our clients, acting as an extended team to help them ship faster, or sometimes we were building new products for our clients, to help them validate their ideas.

Then ChatGPT launched and we saw a flood of demand in AI products. Everyone needed to have their own version of ChatGPT or build something on top of it. A client reached out with a very unique idea. It was aimed to improve productivity in professional communications. I had a discussion with my team and looked into the current available APIs from. We told the client that it's NOT under our area of expertise, but we are confident that we can deliver it. The client agreed. 🤝

A few weeks later, the initial implementation was done and the client launched the product in a few more weeks.

That blew up 🔥 For the client, and down the road, for us as well.

The product started doing really well, since we were very early in the market and solving a real problem. We started showcasing that product as a portfolio to more clients and we started closing more and more projects.

In 2023 alone, we worked on and shipped 14+ AI based products. This has now become a snowball effect. We have worked on so many basic to advance level projects, solved so many problems, that we are now able to consult the best possible solutions to anyone who's coming up with an AI product idea.

Despite all that fear of recession, we were able to stay in business, grow our team, and up skill ourselves, just because of AI.

And the situation is same in 2024. Most of the work we are doing is still on AI.

So AI never took our job. It actually helped us create more jobs and retain ours.

"We do this not because it is easy. But because we thought it would be easy"

Ignorance is a bliss for founders. If the founders knew how hard and painful it's going to be. They wouldn't start. If they could somehow foresee all the pain, suffering, embarrassment, risks, fear, they wouldn't start.

"Oh I just need a basic web/mobile app. Don't worry much about best practices or a good UI. It's just an MVP"

This kind of statement is an ideal example of:

"They don't even know what they don't even know"

I mean, clients really don't know how "bad" a UI can be designed. Without the help of our amazing UI/UX wizards, we, developers, can mess up the designs pretty bad on our own.

And it has happened to us a couple of times. A client once asked us to build a simple one-pager web app, display some simple data on it, just a small simple job, that could lead to some bigger engagements. And he said "Don't worry about the UI. You can make something bare bone on your own"

Our developers completed the whole thing, but the UI was just terrible. But they didn't think much of it, since client never asked for it, and they delivered the end product to the client. And the client just got mad. I jumped in, assured them that we'll get the UI improved and delivered a better version in a day, but they kind of lost faith (a bit too soon) and just wanted to end the engagement. We refunded the client and learned this lesson the hard way.

Now we have a base rule.

No matter what the clients ask for, we have our own quality standards that we have to deliver no matter what. Even if they don't ask for a UI, our UX team will quickly mockup something reasonable enough. Even if they specifically ask not to worry about good practices, we'll follow our own good practices no matter what.

Because at the end of the day, we'll be known by the kind of work we'll deliver for our clients.

Investing on delivering quality products is the best marketing investment.

It's really hard to delegate something which you are not good at yourself.

Be it engineering, sales, planning, marketing or hiring.

If you are not willing to be on the ground and solve each and every problem yourself, it's really hard, if not impossible, to maintain the quality.

It's not easy, but it's a harsh reality that everyone realizes sooner or later.

It doesn't make sense for AI to write code to build software/apps. Hear me out.

"Code" or "Programming Languages" are an interface for humans to interact with computers. The very basic level is binary. Then Assembly came in as a layer of abstraction, then C and C++, and then all the other languages that build on top of them. All these languages just allow "humans" to instruct computers to perform some specific actions.

DALL-E doesn't run a Photoshop instance to design the images. It just create a bunch of pixels purely based on the data it's trained on and it has learned. Sora doesn't fire up Adobe Premiere Pro or Adobe After effects to create videos. It just creates them frame by frame, pixel by pixel, out of nothing. That's how these Large Language Models work.

Now coming back to programming, the Co-Pilot usecase makes a lot of sense, since it's helping people improve their code or review their code. But if we are talking about a complete application being developed by AI, it'll be more like how DALL-E and Sora works.

- You input some prompt to build some features in a web app or mobile or desktop app
- It just creates an executable binary or return a link for a deployed version for you to play around
- Maybe it can show you a preview or "Expo-like" link where's it's not creating an entire build everytime, but a debug live preview link
- If you need to make any changes, you can write follow up prompts and it'll just create a new build for you, like "Hot Reload" or "Instant Run"

Makes sense, right? Think about it!

Sorry Devin, no offense!

I always used to say: "Be a problem solver. The world has enough ReactJS developers"

But I think now I need to add to it: "... and Devin"

Yesterday when I saw the demo of Devin, first thing that came to my mind was:

"Isn't it just like AutoGPT, but more user friendly?"

For those who don't know, AutoGPT launched soon after OpenAI launched GPT-4 and it was basically just a GitHub repo. You set that up locally, add your GPT-4 api keys and run that on a terminal. You allow AutoGPT to perform actions on your behalf and write a prompt of the "Goal" you want to achieve. It searched on the internet, researched everything and performed the actions by prompting itself back and forth.

Though the results were not always very reliable (as per my research back then) so it never caught much attention.

Yesterday Devin just made everyone, and by everyone I mean all the software engineers, panic. And you should really be panicing if you are not evolving with time. Not learning something new everyday or not keeping yourself up to date with the latest advances in technology. The primitive jobs like building a landing page or a stripe integration or creating a simple mobile app will be replaced soon enough, if they haven't already. Or even a bit more complex ones as well.

But what about that huge application that a company is already working on, with hundreds of code files, with a DB schema created by "human software engineers" (HSEs), with the naming conventions assigned by HSEs, with the architecture that involves integrations from 20 different third party services and involves deployment on a very custom cloud infrastructure. Is this all going be automated with Devin? I won't say it won't be, but the more complex the usecase and the problem, the harder it will be for AI agents to replace the human-element altogether.

So be a problem solver. If you have been surviving in the software industry with just surface level skills, it's about time you upgrade your skills and make AI the center of your skillset. So if someone who's not using AI can do something in 1 week, you should be doing that using AI, much faster and way better in a day or two (or less? Maybe)

So let's welcome Devin, whether you like him or not. He has already taken a seat just beside you in your office and he's so eager to compete.

Transparency is everything - All Hands 2024!

We conducted our All Hands this month. A much awaited one. 

In the last couple of months, we made some critical policy changes and did some restructuring. The ones that were really hard to do, but had to be done.

After all, if you are giving your 9 hours a day (or sometime more) to a company, you deserve to know how it's doing. Is there any growth potential? Why some changes were made? And why some of our amazing team members had to leave?

Before the All Hands, I circulated an anonymous form in our Slack channel for the questions the team wants to ask us, without having their identities revealed. I literally asked the team to be "brutal" with their questions.

So we started by following up on the promises and the goals we defined in our last all hands, clearly stating which ones we were able to successfully pull off this year, which ones ended up in the bucket of failed experiments, and which ones are still in progress.

Like all initial stage companies (we are 2 years and 8 months old), we made some mistakes. And we acknowledged them. We discussed how we could have avoided them and how we plan to improve going forward.

We shared the numbers of how we are doing financially. Our revenue for this year was slightly more than last year, but since we scaled the team, our expense increased a lot more and we couldn't hit the revenue goals that we needed to hit to maintain a sustainable & competitive business model.

It also might have been the recession all around the world, but we can only look at the factors that we can control.

So we laid down a plan to tackle all of these problems. The plan that's not a product of my own mind, but something I came up with after having discussion with some mentors, reading some books, and trying to find answers online.

- We need to be laser focus.
- Scale up what's working. Close down what's not.
- Start disqualifying clients and focus on longer term engagements only
- Maintain and build better relationships

& the most important of all.

Quality engineering should be our highest priority. Nothing should come in the way of us building highest quality products for our clients

I hope the next All Hands will have more team members, a bigger hall and all revenue goals smashed. InShaAllah.

Our Quality.
Ownership.
Our love for the trait.

Winner don’t blame, they own - are you working with winners?

Winners don't rely on others to win. They have their own plan, and choose the people who they think can help them win. If one of the actors is not going according to plan, they assess, try to help and if nothing works, they move on and find what's going to work for them.

It might be a bit ruthless for you, as the vendor, but for your customer, it's the only thing that'll make their business successful.

And you really, ONLY, wanna work with the customers who are eager to make their business successful.

Focus on this and it'll push you towards excellence. A win-win for everyone.

Choose to work with “winning” customers. Why?

The same reason why universities and colleges grant scholarships to the good performers. They are betting on winning horses.

The customers with the winning attitude will become your recurring clients at the end. Their business will thrive, the work you’d have done for them and the relation you’d have built with them will result in recurring business.

It’s really hard to ensure sustainability if you choose work with just about anyone and everyone. They’ll lose because of their own incompetencies, and will blame you for not being able to make it big.

Choose very carefully who you do business with.

"How do I know if I am taking all the right decisions?" 

You won’t. 

And you’ll mess up hard.

And you’ll learn.

And next one will be a bit better than the previous one.

You can read all the best books in the world, listen to all the wisest people in the world, watch all those intellectual podcasts, but you won't learn your lessons until you've faced those issues yourself.

You really have to walk that road yourself, face those challenges, take the hit on your face and then try to figure out how to get out of that situation.

Reading books, listening to people and asking for advice, these things help, as long as you are taking the actions yourself. You are never going to figure out that "winning formulae", copy it, and make it big.

If that were the case, all those big investors would be replicating their money by betting on same formulae again and again.

It's more about the "executor" than the "execution"

You won't figure out what you did different, it can be a random candid conversation with someone that can help you close a deal of the lifetime, or it can be the result of all that hard work of yours.

And the sad part, if the luck isn't with you, all that hard work and all those "strategies" are not going to work anyway.

So do what's in your control, do it consistently, and hope something sticks.

No amount of marketing, solves a bad product! 
 
I heard this in a Gary Vaynerchuk video a long time ago and it got stuck with me. You can have the perfect logo, a video that catches your audience's attention right away, a PR strategy that shapes the narrative of the audience for your product, exactly as you want, but at the end of day, when your prospect converts to a customer and the product or the service doesn't deliver what was promised, they'll go away, very frustrated with your reputation shattered.


In the journey of any startup or any product, you are always inclined towards doing the “cool” stuff, because everyone else is doing it. You wanna have a podcast to represent your product, a team building nice videos with prototype of your app, a sales team going on events and posting pictures with high profile clients, and while focusing on all of this, you fail to focus on the most important thing, the product itself.


In the initial days of any startup, you really need to focus on:


🛠 Building the product in the right away

🤝 Focusing on the customer’s pain points

📈 Targeting small achievable goals

😇 Do not market what you are not going to ship

🙌🏼 Saving yourself from the peer pressure of doing the cool things


Do this, build a good product, and then you can go as crazy on the marketing as you want to.

The biggest mistake Non-Tech founders make is, they have an idea, they don't write it down to the finest detail, and expect some freelancer/company to read their mind.

As a Non-Tech founder, you have the leverage of thinking freely without any technical constraints.

I'd recommend staying that way.

Note down everything you have in your mind, create rough wireframes, create your whole vision, the user journey, the user experience on a piece of paper. Don't worry about what's technically possible. Take a piece of paper and go crazy. Let the tech guys worry about what's possible and what's not.

Some of our best clients are Non-tech founders, and some of the worst experiences we've had are with Non-tech founders as well. The difference? The good ones clearly communicate each and every requirement and don't run on assumptions. The not-so-good-ones will just assume that since they've asked you to build a chat app, you'll have all the features of WhatsApp, stories, audio notes, Voice & Video call, already baked in.

Software engineering and product development is an art. And an artist will only be able to draw what you ask them or show them. Nothing more. Nothing less.

"I can either do so many things, or nothing at all"

I battle with this everyday. 

My day starts, and I have too many things to do.

I can focus on sales and outreach and build my network through all those channels I am experimenting with these days.

I can focus on those two really interesting SaaS ideas that I really wanna work on.

I can work on my personal branding.

I can work on planning the upcoming content for company's social medias.

I can read that book, recommended to me by 3 people, that's waiting on my table for a bit too many days now.

I can reach out to potential partners for collaborations.

I can work on improving and streamlining the sales process.

OR.

I can do nothing at all.

I can just keep thinking about all of these things.

Battle with what I should do today. What I should do tomorrow.

And the day ends.

Yup, I know the answer is focusing on one thing at a time. Delegating things. Dividing my time. Prioritizing things, but it's easier said than done.

Working on it...

#entrepreneurship#agencylife#focus#productivity
It's hard. It's risky. The most accurate representation...

"I can do engineering. I'll just hire someone for sales and it'll be taken care of"

NOPE.

It's really hard to delegate something that you are not good at yourself. Not saying it's impossible, just really really hard.

It was always easier for me to build an engineering team, create good engineering processes, because I was going through all of it myself. I knew ins and outs of engineering, the issues faced by engineers, and what makes a good software product. My expertise in it helped me delegate the engineering easily. I won't say I have mastered it, there's a lot of room for improvement, but it's working.

But sales!

If there's anything I have been focusing on for the past two and half years, it's sales. I have been learning about sales, trying out new techniques, reading new books, learning about how to pitch, how to present myself and the brand. You have to learn ins and outs of the sales to properly run a business.

I mean, of course you can hire VP of sales having 10-20 years of experience, but as an initial stage company, you can either not afford that at all, and even if you can, and you are relying on that one individual to bring in cashflow to the company. Congrats, you have just gotten yourself into a bigger problem.

Sustainability of YOUR business now lies in the hands of one person, which is not YOU.

It's a hard to swallow pill, but if you have stepped into business/entrepreneurship, sales is the going to be the only thing that's either going to help you scale, or hold you back. And you want to make sure that you know, of all people, how to do it. You have to show it to your team that:

1. It's possible
2. YOU are able to do it, if no one else can

Trust goes both ways - Do you really trust your team? If not, how do you expect them to trust you?

You cannot build a trustworthy team with motivational speeches, pizza parties & cool hoodies. You build trust the by showing them that you trust them.

From very early days, I started engaging the team members directly with the clients. The team members working on the project talk to the client directly. No middleman. And I received some really good response from my team about this. They were surprised that the company was entrusting them with so much responsibility and giving them ownership.

And the result? They tried to protect that trust with the core of their hearts.

How do I know that?

Two of our clients tried to offer direct employments to our team members, and my team members reported that directly to me. I never intervened. I let the team member handle it by themselves. They told them it'd be a breach of contract and violation of rules.

I also started trusting my team, from very early on, with company financials. The team prepares financial estimates for the projects, they know what kind of projects we work on, what we charge, and they negotiate with the client on behalf of the company as well, taking client through the whole journey, from discovery, till closing.

And this trust has allowed me to unlink myself from day to day of the business and delegate the responsibilities to my team. It's because of this trust that I have been able to travel abroad 4 times this year, and there was no disruption in the work we were delivering to the client and in closing new clients.

I am able to experiment with different ways of sales, growing business, personal branding - just because of this trust, that:

👇🏻 they've got me covered 💯

Or maybe you might have figured that out for that one particular situation or some specific span of time or for a particular scale of problem.

The problem will keep evolving, keep getting harder and harder, and as you start to grow, the scale of the problem and the effects that the problem will have will keep getting bigger.

Hope for the best, plan for the worst.

The Failure Story - When I lost my years of hard work and a few thousand $$$, because of a single client 💔

My freelance journey started within the last year of my University, and it went decently well. I was usually overburdened with the amount of work, so I was handing it off to my friends most of the time, so much so, that at one time, there were 10 projects in progress and I was working on none of them, all being done by my friends. And yes, the process was always transparent and the clients always knew who was working on the project.

We had a client who wanted us to build web scrappers for him. I started working on that with my friend. We completed more than 10 projects for him and worked with him for over an year. Ultimately, the scrappers started breaking because of various factors. The client started arguing every other day and it seemed like it'd end one day or the other. So one day, I gathered some courage and told him it's not working out for us anymore and we want to end the contracts, even the ones currently in progress that we have worked on. He agreed and ended the contracts.

Next day, I received a bunch of notifications.

"Your project has been cancelled"
"Your project has been cancelled"
"Your project has been cancelled"
.....
.....

The client had reversed the payment for all of the work we had done for him over the past year using Paypal chargeback (Google about it and you'll find a lot of victims of chargeback)

I used to withdraw funds from my account every few weeks, so the account only had around $1000 at that time. I lost that amount, plus my account went in negative. Which meant, if I work on any new projects, the earning will be eaten away by the negative balance.

It took me 2 years to build that account. So many 5 star reviews. All lost, because of 1 bad client. I reached out to support and asked them to check all the 5-star reviews that the client had given us over the past years, but they couldn't do anything because it was a chargeback. It was out of their control (they could file a dispute to Paypal, but I guess they just never bothered)

I had a good enough stream of income at that time, but everything was killed by one client. I was never able to recover that account again, but I had a few clients outside of the platform, so I kept working with them as well.

Now when I look back, I think it was for the good.

I would have never tried Upwork, if my Fiverr account was fine.
I might have never started RipeSeed, which mainly started as an Upwork Agency.
I might have never been able to run an agency of 28 people.

As heartbreaking as that was at that time, I think that was a key factor in who I am today.

Why I am working as a solo founder and don't have partners? I get this question a lot and was planning to document the answer in a post, so here it goes.

Knowing myself well enough, I think I'd have messed up the partnership myself if I had one. Different people have different energies and I think it'll be hard for me, personally, to match my energies with the other person, hence resulting in conflicts later on.

Now, what are the benefits of not having partners:

- Faster Decision Making ~ I can quickly make good/bad decisions, if that works, great, if not, I can pivot without any long discussions.

- No judgments ~ Accept it or not, the human mind does not like to hear no for an answer. If you give an opinion to your partner and he/she says no, the next time, you'll think twice about giving an opinion, which will hinder experimentation.

- Not relying on anyone ~ If I know I am the only one, I'll have no option, no excuse, for not doing something. Sales, engineering, planning, marketing, I know I am the only one responsible. I won't be relying on anyone else.

- Talking less. Doing more ~ I mean, we all love making plans. Romanticizing about the future and the possibilities. Daydreaming. And sometimes, these things start taking up too much of your time. When your partners are your friends, sometimes it can take too much time "making plans", and less time "executing them"


However, I think partnerships can be great if done right. Whenever someone asks me, whether or not they should do partnerships, this is what I recommend:

- Build alone. Then merge ~ This will help both of you to validate that you can build something from the ground up. Build something small, make it profitable. Once both of you validate your capabilities, then you can merge. This is especially helpful if both founders have the same area of expertise, which is mostly the case.

- Split responsibilities ~ This helps you stay clear about which person is accountable for which part of the business. If both of you are doing exactly the same thing, one of them will have the leverage to slack off, with the excuse of "It's being done by him anyway"

- Make sure your goals align ~ Every individual has personal goals. With partnerships, you have to make sure that those goals, either align or do not come in the way of your mutual goal.


Having partners is great. You can have someone to share the good and bad times with because you cannot always share those successes and failures with your friends and family. But you have to know yourself well enough. If you think you think you can perform well under a partnership, go for it. Everyone paves their own road to their goals. There is no, one, well-defined recipe for success. Have faith and take the leap 🚀

A step-by-step guide on failing miserably at launching a SaaS product:

🧠 Don't share your idea with anyone, don't validate it at all. Your idea is precious. The moment you share it, someone else will develop it and make a couple million dollars.

🛠️ Start with tens of features and don't launch until all of them are developed.

🗑️ Have unrealistic expectations from your development team and push them to deliver results faster than possible. They'll build a bunch of unsustainable garbage so all your features are developed

📣 Don't define a target market. Your product is for everyone. The whole world needs it. Don't narrow it down to region, industry, and age group.

🚻 Have zero public presence. Don't market it on social networks. Just launch and wait for users to discover your product

Congrats. You have successfully failed in launching a SaaS product 👏🏻

No one starts with a rock-solid process. But you gotta start somewhere. A bad process is better than no process at all. 

And sometimes, having a process can be something as simple as just staying consistent with whatever you are doing.

1. We do twice a week sales meetings, sometimes they feel a bit redundant, but consistent meetings allow us to catch any issues right away. If there is lack of leads generated in any particular week, we all come together and see what we can do to improve it, and most of the time, some minor changes in strategy produce great results.

2. We created our own process of handing off leads from sales to the technical team, it took a few iterations and now the process is pretty solid and the client hardly ever feels inconvenienced with the hand-off.

3. In the early days, we started using Notion to manage all the projects, creating tickets and managing a whole task board in a notion doc. Some might say it's not a "good practice", you should always use Jira/Asaana/Trello, but one of our clients, who had the experience of working with a team much bigger than us, complemented as "You guys are much more organized than the previous ones"

4. Being an AWS enthusiast, I started training everyone on AWS myself from day one, whenever we hired someone. I created a basic training document and shared it with the team. The team then started training new joiners based on that doc, and kept improving and working on that doc as well. And now we have training docs for AWS, Web 3, Advanced React Training, and many more.

There is no single formula that can work for everyone. You might have to just create your own recipe, stay consistent about it and make it work. You will never know if something is working on not if you are not following anything consistently.

Create a process. Stay consistent.
If it works, great.
If it doesn't, pivot.
Repeat.

An app I built, in 2 hours, ended up hitting 150k+ downloads 🚀

Back in 2017, I got this new phone, it was Motorola Z Play I guess. It had a flash for both front and back cameras. Pretty cool. I tried looking for apps that could turn on both flashlights at the same time, and I found none. So I decided to build one on my own.

Created some simple designs in Photoshop, developed the whole app in like 2 hours, and just released it. It worked on my phone, so I thought, “Good, one more app in the portfolio”. Didn't think of it much at that time.

A few days later, I decided to post about it in some forums like XDA Developers. No paid marketing or any ASO. I hardly knew anything about ASO at that time. Fast forward a few weeks, and the app got like 50k+ downloads 🤯 I wasn’t expecting that at all. Then I checked back again in a few months, more downloads, and to this date, the app has gotten 150k+ downloads 🎉

How? Don't know. Organically, maybe some XDA users, or maybe because I decided to randomly build some stuff, without overthinking about design, perfection, or any marketing, and launched right away. It's still live on Play Store 👉

Hope this gives someone enough motivation to start working on that hobby project of theirs that they have been thinking about for a long time!!

How waking up early for a client, helped build a relationship worth $50k+

Six months into's journey, I got to talk to an Australian Health Tech giant, having a big team of developers and researchers. They were planning to automate a huge manual workflow that was consuming billable hours of their own engineers. After a couple of meetings, they agreed to work with me - with one condition. They wanted me to be part of their standup call and needed an overlap of 5 hours.

Australia is 5 hours ahead of us, which meant I had to be in the meeting at 8:00 AM in the morning. Which also meant that I had to wake up at 6:30 AM, get ready, have breakfast and travel to office, so I can attend the meeting at 8 AM. And I am not an early riser. I can sleep as late as 4 AM, but I can't wake up easily. (Not proud of it)

But it could be our first enterprise client if I could handle them correctly. So I signed up. Every day in the office, at around 7:45 AM, attending the meetings, working on automating the workflow, establishing a good relationship with our point of contact and the team on their side, and after about a month and a half, we were able to deliver the solution that they hired us for. The engineering manager who hired me showcased workflow in a company-wide meeting and everyone just clapped. And I had never seen them clapping in any of the meetings before.

It established a strong relationship and trust. The initial contract ended in 3 months, but we stayed in touch if they needed anything from me. And then after 3 more months, they reached out again, with the need for a Senior Full Stack engineer, and we were able to assign one of our team members to work for them. And it seemed like that effort of waking up early was finally paying off.

I rely on Notion heavily for my day-to-day workflow. And have been relying on it since day one. 

It's critical to start organizing things from early on, because if you don't, things get messy, sooner than you can realize.

I wanted to make sure each and everything I was doing, related to HR, Accounts, Engineering, and Sales, was documented. Now I could either buy a separate SaaS tool for each of these things, or I could just create my own workflow in Notion, so that's what I did.

1. Instead of using Jira, I started managing projects on Notion, using their Task Board component. I could filter the tickets, assign different tags, assign to different team members, add details to each tickets and comment on them as well. Everything that a basic task management tool should do.

2. Instead of using an HRMS, I used Tables component, added my comments, candidate's contact details, and their interview status using tags. I was also doing regular meetings with existing team members and taking notes in the HR document as well

3. Instead of using a CRM initially, I created a document to add my notes of all the meetings I was having with the clients.

4. When we built Sales and Client Success Team, I started keeping notes of my meetings with the teams in a Notion doc, so in every other meeting, we could revisit what we discussed in the previous one.

As we started growing, we did end up using a dedicated HRMS with more features, started using Hubspot to track leads and had a separate workflow for accounts, but to this day, everything that I am directly dealing with, goes in Notion.

"Follow-ups" are crucial in sales and client communication.

"But, wouldn't that make me appear desperate?"

To whom? Let go of that pride.

We acquired our first game development client solely because of follow-ups. This client was in talks with several other companies and was uncertain about the approach to their solution. After our initial meeting, we didn't hear from them for about 3-4 days. So I sent a follow-up.

The client responded right away. They weren't entirely certain if the final product would match their vision. They sought a quick prototype and tools to test their idea.

After discussing this with my team, we proposed building a small prototype within a week for the client to validate the core game idea. They agreed, and we initiated a small contract. In just one week, our end result satisfied the client, leading us to secure the full contract to develop the game. That game remains in our portfolio, a showcase for our clients to this day.

Without that one game, we might not even have a game development team today. And where did it all begin? With that one "follow-up."

This hypothesis was recently validated when we initiated an outbound email campaign. The "Open Rate" for the initial batch of emails was 5%, while the second follow-up achieved a 30% "Open Rate". The Sales Gurus in my network can validate this hypothesis.

The moral of the story: Always follow up ✅ Leave that pride at home when you step into sales.

You never know, from day one, which client is going to be a long-term client. You have to just take your chances with every client you work with, provide the best service possible, and hope they turn out to be the good ones and appreciate your effort.

This client first came to us in February, earlier this year, and we started working on hisproduct idea. The initial version was released within 1 to 1.5 months and then we kept working on further iterations of the project. We formed a good relationship, based on the quality of our work and then he came up with another project and then another. So far we have worked on 3 of his projects, maintaining the previous ones, while working on his new ideas.

Was there any strategy involved in specifically acquiring THIS 👇🏻 client? No.

It's the numbers game. You reach out to as many people as you possibly can, hoping they'd turn out to be the ones with good ideas and patience, and you just work with them. Some of them turn out to be longer-term clients like him, while some just give up.

You just have to make sure you are not the one who is giving up.

Don't get caught in the never-ending cycle of building features and never releasing 🔄

We have worked with clients who truly had some brilliant ideas, but could not put a cap on their ideas and thought every new idea they had, "had to be in the initial release", or everything we've built so far is trash. Kept delaying the release again and again, resulting in higher upfront investment, and increased chance of potential bugs that could happen because of unforeseen user experience issues.

On the other hand, we've also had the opportunity to work with some brilliant clients who:

🔬 planned a minimal set of features for their initial release
🚀 got the first version out in 1 month
👥 worked towards acquiring users
🤝 iterated on the next set of features based on user feedback
💵 started generating revenue within a few weeks of launch

Don't assume what your user is going to like. Just ask, and they might just tell you what they are willing to pay for.

Release as soon as you can. Build the core value that your product can provide, and that additional feature you very much want to have in your product can be added after the initial release is out. Best of luck 🙌

"So, I can go home and watch Netflix, but I cannot go home and freelance, is that what you mean?"

Back in 2019, when I was interviewing for a bunch of companies, I was always surprised when some interviewer or HR said:

"We don't allow freelancing"
"We have a zero-tolerance policy on freelancing"

I was like, why? I can go home and play games, I can watch movies, but I cannot freelance? Doesn't make any sense. I want to work on my own thing, I have some personal goals, and I'll make sure that my freelance thing will not interfere with my day-to-day job. So why am I not allowed to freelance?

It never made sense to me. I got 6 job offers when I graduated, and I made sure to mention my preference to freelance in the interview. I wanted to make this stance clear. I was not planning to lie to the employer and do it anyway.

In 2021, when RipeSeed started, I started encouraging my team members to do their own thing if they wanted to. I always encouraged them to do freelance if that makes them happy. If they have their own product ideas, they are free to discuss with me anytime they want, and I'll be happy to help to the best of my knowledge.

You cannot build a great team if your team thinks you don't care about their growth. Why I am working as a solo founder and don't have partners? I get this question a lot and was planning to document the answer in a post, so here it goes.

Knowing myself well enough, I think I'd have messed up the partnership myself if I had one. Different people have different energies and I think it'll be hard for me, personally, to match my energies with the other person, hence resulting in conflicts later on.

Now, what are the benefits of not having partners:

- Faster Decision Making ~ I can quickly make good/bad decisions, if that works, great, if not, I can pivot without any long discussions.

- No judgments ~ Accept it or not, the human mind does not like to hear no for an answer. If you give an opinion to your partner and he/she says no, the next time, you'll think twice about giving an opinion, which will hinder experimentation.

- Not relying on anyone ~ If I know I am the only one, I'll have no option, no excuse, for not doing something. Sales, engineering, planning, marketing, I know I am the only one responsible. I won't be relying on anyone else.

- Talking less. Doing more ~ I mean, we all love making plans. Romanticizing about the future and the possibilities. Daydreaming. And sometimes, these things start taking up too much of your time. When your partners are your friends, sometimes it can take too much time "making plans", and less time "executing them"


However, I think partnerships can be great if done right. Whenever someone asks me, whether or not they should do partnerships, this is what I recommend:

- Build alone. Then merge ~ This will help both of you to validate that you can build something from the ground up. Build something small, make it profitable. Once both of you validate your capabilities, then you can merge. This is especially helpful if both founders have the same area of expertise, which is mostly the case.

- Split responsibilities ~ This helps you stay clear about which person is accountable for which part of the business. If both of you are doing exactly the same thing, one of them will have the leverage to slack off, with the excuse of "It's being done by him anyway"

- Make sure your goals align ~ Every individual has personal goals. With partnerships, you have to make sure that those goals, either align or do not come in the way of your mutual goal.


Having partners is great. You can have someone to share the good and bad times with because you cannot always share those successes and failures with your friends and family. But you have to know yourself well enough. If you think you think you can perform well under a partnership, go for it. Everyone paves their own road to their goals. There is no, one, well-defined recipe for success. Have faith and take the leap 🚀
