Unlinking yourself from the day-to-day of your business operations is the most critical thing you need to do!

When we started, it was me:

💰 Doing all the sales ----------------- 30%
🎙️ Talking to all the clients ------------ 30%
👨🏻‍💻 Managing all the projects ---------- 22%
🏤 Hiring new people ----------------- 16%
🧠 Thinking about how to grow --------- 2%

This is, percentage-wise, how my energy and thought process were divided. Notice what's wrong?

I was engaged so much in the day-to-day of the business that thinking about how to grow and experimenting with new things was extremely difficult. But luckily, I was aware of this problem and I was aiming to get out of the day-to-day operations as soon as I possibly could.

With a bit of effort and spending some time, we were able to build a sales process, that could lift that burden off of me. The sales team was able to reach out to clients, just like me, and we were able to get leads we could convert into clients.

The next part took time, and it was the responsibility of getting on initial client calls whenever a lead was generated by our Sales team. I was partially worried, but not too focused on solving this problem. Until the end of last year, when I was about to get married. I figured if I didn't lift this responsibility off of me, it would either affect the business or my personal life.

So we built a Client Success Team, just 10 days before my wedding. A group of extremely talented, skilled engineers, who will be going on the initial client calls, and closing clients on behalf of the company, with the potential of getting bonuses for every client they close. Within a month or two, that team started closing clients, and those "closers" started managing their projects as well.

This has now allowed me to focus on the growth of the company. I have started learning more about sales, reading more books about how to grow the business, doing partnerships to spread the word about our services, attending more networking events, and of course, personal branding.

So right now, almost 90%, if not more, of my brain capacity is focused on growth and experimenting with new ways to generate sales.

Hope this helps anyone who's struggling with a similar problem and can motivate them enough to start focusing on unlinking themselves from the day-to-day of their business as well.

Back in December 2022, we got our first Generative AI client, not strategically, but accidentally, and that proved to be a blessing for us!


Our team at that time was not heavily skilled in core AI/ML, so if any AI/ML client reached out to us, we were either saying no to them or just getting help from our partners or contractors.


So when this client came, I reached out to one of our contractors, who's also a close friend of mine, to help us out with it. We had a meeting with the client and everything went well. The client agreed to continue with us. I had a discussion about it with the team and we figured we don't really need a custom AI/ML solution for it. We could just use's APIs. At that time, ChatGPT's official API was not out, so we just used DaVinci model of the Text Completion AI.


Now that client was super passionate about his product as well. He didn't just hire us to let us work on it, sit back and relax. He was actively making content on his socials to spread awareness about his product, sharing the whole journey of development. When we showed him some initial results, he made a video on his socials, screaming with happiness "THEY DID IT!!! 🎉" We were happy, of course, but now the stakes were even higher, because if we messed up, he'd sure as hell announce that in a video.


Turns out, the project was delivered on time, everything went much better than expected, and because of the marketing the client was doing already, he got a good number of paying customers within the first month of launch. It was an amazing success.


's API was launched much later, and when it did, we replaced the Text Completion with ChatGPT's API and everything kept working as it should.


That proved huge for us. We used that success in our portfolio. Then the Gen AI craze started and the market got saturated with a bunch of startups and products based on Gen AI. Every client we talked to, got impressed with our portfolio and awarded their project to us. We kept delivering successful projects and kept adding to the list of successful Gen AI projects.


We did not make any strategic plans to hop on the Gen AI hype, but somehow, coincidentally, we did, and that proved huge for us.

Smile, be more approachable, and avoid using negative words!

I was once talking to a client, and after around 10 minutes of discussion, he said:

"I like talking to you, you have this nice smile on your face"

Yes, I keep the cameras ON while talking to new clients. It builds credibility and they get all kinds of positive gestures through your facial expressions.

Whenever you are talking to a potential client or any new prospect, they have all these concerns in their mind, whether or not you can deliver, whether you are a good communicator or not, or if you have what it takes to do what they want.

If you really wanna build a strong relationship, you have to make sure that the other side feels comfortable talking to you and raising their concerns.

Our team is trained to avoid using negative phrases or negative terms at every cost. So instead of saying:


"No, we don't agree with this approach"

We say:

"Hmm.. that's good, however, what if we do it like...."


Notice the difference? You communicated your approach without even denying theirs.

People don't like to hear no for an answer. Especially if they are paying you. It depends on you how to reach the end goal successfully, by keeping all stakeholders happy and making them feel they are part of the decision-making process.

A good sleep solves everything 😴

Happened to me countless times. I figured this “like hack” out pretty early in my career, that the solution to a lot of problems can be a good sleep.


👉 Tensed about a project? Couldn’t figure it out? Slept. I woke up and the problem that seemed hard just solved itself.

👉 A client was asking for too much additional work, driving me crazy, and I was just about to lose it. I just slept, hoping I’d wake up with a better solution. And I did. Talked to the client and found common ground.

👉 Something not going right in the office? Just went home and without overthinking, I slept. And when I woke up, I could see the situation wasn’t as bad as my mind was showing it to me.


Everyone burns out. You can push yourself to a certain limit only, after that, your brain efficiency declines and you start to panic over very simple and small problems. Sleep is like a debugger for your brain and can help you out with problem-solving and creativity.

Hope this post motivates someone enough to get a good 8-9 hours of sleep tonight :)

You ask anyone, "How important is personal branding?" and they'll say "A LOT!!"

And then you ask, "Are you doing it?", and they'll be like "🤐"


I have been making these excuses to myself for many years,

"I don't have time" (A LIE!)
"It'll look cringe" (To the ones who are not even my target audience)
"I won't be able to continue" (You first need to start, and then you can worry about continuing)
"I'll run out of content" (Just START!!!)


Many people were telling me to start writing content, and even some of my team members, whom I was trying to motivate for personal branding, were like:


"Hashir Bhai aap to start krain, aapky pas to itna kuch hy btany k liye"
(English) "Hashir, you should start, you have so much content"


And then I started reading this book named "Little Red Book of Selling" byand there was this line:


"It's not about who you know, it's about who knows YOU"


And it clicked 🫰 You can be the best one out there, you might know so much more than others, you might have the perfect solution for someone, but if people never know you, you don't exist.

“We don't want someone who's driven by money” Bro everyone is driven by money. You are running a business? You are driven by money, the most! Cut the crap!


“But we are a startup, aiming to raise some funding” So if I understand it correctly, you want to make money without spending money. Right?


“But our business will change the world and people’s lives” You are not willing to make this one person’s life better. You can worry about the world later.


“We want to hire someone who works towards the company’s success, not just for money” It’s your company. You need to work towards its success. And part of the job is to hire good people, and that costs money.


These statements can be heard from recruiters and clients alike. I’ve just given you answers to all of them.


Whenever someone says “we are not looking for someone who’s driven by money” and still asks you to work for them, be alarmed that the person is trying to manipulate you.


Everyone has personal ambitions, situations, and life goals, you can’t expect people to work for your ambition, by being as ambitious as yourself. But if you really want to make them ambitious about your ambition, make sure they are rewarded for it, and can clearly see how the fulfillment of your ambition will make them successful as well.

You can be transparent & honest about your processes and can still survive and thrive in a business.

In the early days, a lot of the clients said “No” because of our transparency, because they needed to work with someone having “relevant portfolio” or someone with “years of experience” in the industry. Go ask our clients, I am making this statement publicly, on my public profile:

- we never claimed to have years of experience
- we never claimed to have huge teams
- we never claimed to be based in the US or Europe
- we never claimed to have engineers with 6+ years of experience
- we never faked being an individual and secretly running a company behind the scenes
- we never shadow our team members, clients always know who’s working on the project

Whenever some client was persistent on working with someone with more experience, we had to let go of them and tell them exactly about the team and experience we have. We promise the quality of work. We promised our dedication to deliver their project. We might be late on a deadline, but we’ll be transparent about what’s happening in the project.

We might not be the best ones out there, but we damn sure wanna be the honest one.

Clients lack trust in working with agencies, because of the shady practices used by them. We are willing to limit our growth if that’s the cost of being honest and transparent. But if you genuinely ask me about it, I don’t think our growth has been slower. We have been able to grow to a team of 28 people in the short time span of 2 years, Alhamdulillah, and it’s crazy enough for me.

"You can't connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backwards. So you have to trust that the dots will somehow connect in your future. You have to trust in something - your gut, destiny, life, karma, whatever." - Steve Jobs

Now that I look backwards, I can see that.... the dots.... have connected.... just fine!

Do not. Sell anyone. Anything. On Gitex.

People are here to represent themselves, what they've accomplished over the years, what they've built, how they are helping their community, the industry and the ecosystem as a whole.

If you go around, handing out your business cards to everyone you meet, you can assure yourself that the card is going into a bin that night.

How to build a meaningful relation? Listen to what they have to say. Ask meaningful questions, go deeper into what they are representing and how the've come so far. And then you will (probably) hear the other side saying:

"Hey, tell me about you? What do you do?"

And that's when you tell them what you do. If they find value in it, they'll ask to get connected, and you won't even need a business card to build that relation. You just need to listen what they have to say.

This is my strategy in every networking event I go to, and it seems to be working out.

No amount of marketing, solves a bad product! 
 
I heard this in a Gary Vaynerchuk video a long time ago and it got stuck with me. You can have the perfect logo, a video that catches your audience's attention right away, a PR strategy that shapes the narrative of the audience for your product, exactly as you want, but at the end of day, when your prospect converts to a customer and the product or the service doesn't deliver what was promised, they'll go away, very frustrated with your reputation shattered.


In the journey of any startup or any product, you are always inclined towards doing the “cool” stuff, because everyone else is doing it. You wanna have a podcast to represent your product, a team building nice videos with prototype of your app, a sales team going on events and posting pictures with high profile clients, and while focusing on all of this, you fail to focus on the most important thing, the product itself.


In the initial days of any startup, you really need to focus on:


🛠 Building the product in the right away

🤝 Focusing on the customer’s pain points

📈 Targeting small achievable goals

😇 Do not market what you are not going to ship

🙌🏼 Saving yourself from the peer pressure of doing the cool things


Do this, build a good product, and then you can go as crazy on the marketing as you want to.

⚡️ If you deliver the highest quality of work

😇 You remain honest with your client

Two of our clients who didn't know about each other, met each other at a conference and started discussing their products. Somehow they ended up discussing how they were using a team from Pakistan, they mentionedand how they were super satisfied with the work we've done for them. One of those clients pinged and told me this story, like "Hey, I met that other client of yours at an event today"


Like, what are the odds? Two of your clients, somewhere far away in the world, meeting and discussing about your work. Absolutely amazing! We are still working with both of them, developing their SaaS apps, and maintaining the relationship.


Had we not maintained a good relationship with them, we'd end up losing both of those clients that day. You start seeing the results of these things in the longer run. You might not be seeing the results right away, but as you continue to deliver what you promise, keep the client at ease, you'll end up building a reputation for reliability, and I am glad we have built and maintained that sort of relationship with all of our clients.

Everyone's formula for success is different. Don't get discouraged by seeing someone else's journey or path different than yours. What works for them, might not work for you.

🏃🏻‍♂️ For some, waking up early and going for a run, can be an energy boost, while someone can get crazy things done after midnight, alone, on their laptop.

👨🏻‍🏫 For some, getting mentors to guide on each step of the way is helpful, while someone might not be able to think straight with someone spoon-feeding.

🏤 Someone might be able to build a team in 2 weeks, while you are struggling for 4 months and still have just 2 team members. In the long term, 2 weeks or 4 months is a very insignificant amount of time. Ultimately, you'll make it.

It's not about following any particular formulae, it's about consistency. You keep trying until it works.

I should charge less if I am starting out, right? 🤔 No! ❌

Defining the base rules, lower limits, and sticking to them is very critical when you are starting a client servicing business. Everyone starting out thinks if they charge lower for their services, they might be able to secure some initial clients. I wouldn’t agree.

Clients, the good ones, go for quality. Never for price. See what your industry is already charging and charge the same rate.


💪 Compete on quality, commitment, support, reliability.

💸 Do not compete on price. There’s always someone willing to sell for lower than you.


Whenstarted, we had a minimum-maximum range and started saying no to clients in the very early days who were not paying us at least our minimum. Initially, it’s hard to say no when you are starting out. You might close 1 client with your “good price” rather than closing 5 clients with your “lower price”. But it ensures the quality of clients you are adding to your pool. And the pool, eventually, will keep growing.

It’s so hard to up-charge a client who is used to paying you a low price. Not impossible, but pretty hard to convince why you are asking him $10000 for a product when you previously built a similar one for him for $2000. You will never get out of this loop.

But that being said, I’d totally admit that my situation was different and I was privileged. I had a backup for multiple months that I had saved for the past couple of years with jobs and freelancing. So it was easier for me to say no.

So my recommendation would be to:
💵 Build a financial backup first
⚡️ Charge high, so you can pay well to maintain a quality engineering team
✨ Build a reputation for quality & reliability
🤝 Make sure your clients feel you’ve “Got their back”

Strong financial backing is crucial to build a sustainable business because not every month is equally profitable. And it’s your responsibility, as the business owner, to think months ahead, instead of days.

There’s a huge difference between “I’ll do it” and “I’ll do it tomorrow at 5:30 PM”

“Work expands, to the time, allowed for it” - Parkinson’s Law

This is a universal truth. You give me one week to write a post, I’ll finish writing that at the last minute. You give me 1 hour, you’ll have the post ready in 50 minutes. I heard about this law first time in avideo () and since then, I started applying that everywhere.

I noticed sometimes at, we were planning a lot of stuff, but not everything was seeing the light of the day. I found out that we were not “time-bounding” everything. We might be discussing a lot of stuff, aiming to build a social media strategy and post good content, and tech-reels, but we were not adding a deadline to “when we need to do it?”

Earlier last month, I started focusing on that and saw great and instant results.

Starting with myself, I gave myself the goal of writing one post per day. No matter how good or bad. Just one post. It’ll be just me talking about me and what we do as a company. Just have to put them in words. And it started happening. Between 3 to 5 PM every day, my focus is to write a post that I have to publish by 6 or 7 PM. And you can see the consistency.

Then we started focusing on re-shaping ourLinkedIn strategy, thanks to the suggestions from. We started to set a timeframe to create certain kinds of content. We defined a time on a particular day in every week when we shoot the reel, and then we edit and finalize them. We created a backlog of almost a whole month just by following this approach.

Someone from my team said, I had asked that person to provide me something, but I haven’t received anything from them. And I asked, “well, did you ask them to deliver that thing to you in 1 hour or any deadline at all?” And the answer was “Umm… No??” So I sat with them, sent the message with an exact time we needed the deliverable, and guess what? We received it 5 minutes earlier.

This is one of the biggest life hacks I have recently discovered. Start time-bounding everything. From the smallest to the biggest goals, if you don’t have time allocated to them, they won’t happen.

The REAL sale starts after the deal is signed ✍🏻

Most of us think of it the other way around. Signing a deal with the client is not the actual win. That’s just the start of a new relationship, and the real sales work starts after that.

After the deal is signed, the client entrusts you with his reputation, his decision to work with you, and your capabilities to deliver what he wants in a well-defined time. If you can prove to him that his decision to work with you is right, you can turn them into a fan from just a client.


🎯 Make sure your client’s business goal is being met, with what you are doing for them

💼  Your client might be asking for something, not knowing the costs associated with it. Being a solutions provider, it’s your job to tell them about any effects of those changes before you implement them. Your client will thank you for that.

🕵🏻‍♂️ Being a technical solutions provider, it’s your job to suggest features and potential edge cases that your clients might not be even aware of, that are critical for their use-case


At, every person involved in delivering the solution is trained to keep the client’s success in mind while working on the technical solutions. We have faced this situation countless times where the client’s proposed solution wasn’t aligned with their business goal and a little discussion and briefing from our side helped them visualize the final results more clearly.

In a later post, I'll share some examples of how we helped some clients of ours reach their business goals and the kind of appreciation we received from them 🌟

Till then, best of luck!

Absolute Gem 💎 Opportunities are everywhere.

You don’t want to win the deal 🙅 you want to win the heart 💖

I cannot emphasize this enough, trust and relationship comes first. The deal comes at the very last. Whenever you are interacting with a new prospect, consider yourself in their shoes.

A good client will always do his due diligence. He is talking to 10 more people other than you, finding someone he can trust with his money or if he is representing his company, he is even more cautious. His organization has entrusted him to choose a provider and your performance (good or bad) will be considered his performance. So his reputation is at stake, which is worth way more than money 💸

In one of the videos from, I heard him saying something like:

”Be on the same side as the client. You don’t want to be on the opposite side of him and fight with him. You want to be on the same side as him, and have the problem on the other side, and then help him solve that problem”

Only if I could find that video again, he explained that so much better. But this advice really changed my perspective. Whenever I go to calls with new prospects, I go with the aim of solving their problem, the deal will follow if we are actually good at it (and it mostly follows)


Here are a few things I do to change the ton of any meeting and make it favorable for the prospect:

🎥 Turn on the VIDEO. Show them your face. Show them you are a real human being, not someone shadowing someone else, hiding behind a screen.

😬 SMILE. It changes the whole tone of the meeting. Your prospect will be at ease and will be comfortable right away. It also shows you are confident in what you are talking about.

💰 Don’t sell your offerings at every word they say. Try and solve their problem. If they trust your word, they’ll ask how you can help them.

And the hardest one.

😇 Learn to say no to things you can’t do. Tell them if you are not the right fit. Wish them luck. They’ll be back with something in the future. The last thing you want is to pick up something you can’t do and embarrass yourself in front of your client.


You start aiming for the hearts of your prospects and they’ll start converting into your clients with deals 🤝

Not many people know this, but before starting RipeSeed, I started a company named SkillOverDev (yup, that was the name)

I started this while I was doing a job. It was like, if it works, great, if not, what’s the loss? Not much.

There are a bunch of small mistakes I made that resulted in closing that small operation within a month.


1. I kept that company remote only. I hired a person from LinkedIn, good guy, and we started working on a project. It was really tough for me to manage. I was doing the job, plus this side-hustle, and I wasn’t able to create an environment that could inspire anyone.

2. I wasn’t afraid of the results. I didn’t burn my ships and I was always looking at that backup plan all the time if things went south.

3. I wasn’t focused enough. I had more than 70% of my time dedicated elsewhere.

4. I wasn’t invested myself. I was just trying to get the work done through my team and wasn’t invested in the company formation myself.


Hardly a month passed and both of my initial hires left for better opportunities. And guess what, I wasn’t very sad about it, which is very alarming ❗️

I learnt some lessons that helped me later on when I started.


1. I kept myself 100% invested in RipeSeed and nothing else. No side-hustle, no hobby projects, no part-time job, I was doing everything for RipeSeed 🤝

2. I didn’t rely on remote. It’s really hard to form a good culture being a remote company in the early days 💻

3. In the first year or so, I was directly engaged with the team to deliver the projects, but later on, when the team scaled, I started moving into managing things, investing more in team formations, building sales process, and now marketing and branding 🚀


And..... seems like..... it worked 👀

Sharing this little failure story of mine to help anyone planning to take the leap!

A jack of ALL Trade 👷🏻‍♂️ and master of SOME 💪 (not none)

It’s time we get rid of old proverbs and adapt to some new ones. We heard this thing a lot that you need to find a specific niche, you have to be specialized in one particular skill set and master that ONE skill ONLY.

It never made sense to me. I always wanted to be a problem solver, instead of a Frontend Developer, Backend Developer, App Developer or Cloud Architect. Since the time I started working professionally, I never confined myself to any one particular technology. I wanted to learn to build apps, websites, deploy infrastructure, build CI/CD pipelines and anything that could fall in the bracket of “tech”. Because I loved “tech”.

This has helped me a ton while I was working in companies. I always used to find the best solution to any problem, instead of trying to fix every problem with the only skill that I know.

This helped me when I started freelancing, because I could do everything, or even if I couldn’t do everything, I knew what the right solution is.

And this helped me when I started, as I gave the clients the confidence that I knew the problem to their solution. I am not here to sell them a specific tech stack. I am here to help them find the best solution, even if that doesn’t fall under the category of skills I have.

I always advise the same to my team and everyone basically. Be a problem solver, the world already has a bit too many React developers.

An experience that’s so close to my heart ❤️

Back in May 2022, a couple of students reached out, asking to deliver a seminar on the topic of how to start a business through freelancing. I had 0 experience in public speaking, let alone standing in front of 100 people and delivering an hour-long seminar. But I don’t know how, and I said yes.

I had the week to prepare for it, but I waited till last night (obviously) and then all those fears came up:

- My whole team will be at the event, what if I deliver a terrible speech and embarrass them?
- What if no one is interested in the whole back story that I think is critical?
- What if people laugh?
- I am risking the whole brand image of RipeSeed on this one, possibly stupid, decision of mine. Whatever I do at that seminar will be linked to the name of the company.

I started preparing for it that night. Wrote the whole thing, started rehearsing, and the plan was to have my phone open and deliver the speech. Or at least look at the bullet points.

The next day I was at the seminar, my team was there and we were just waiting for the exact time. The hall started filling up and since the topic was interesting, the hall filled up with over 100 students. I tested the mic and without overthinking a lot, I started.

And then guess what happened?



Nothing.



I talked for over 40 minutes, I hardly looked at my phone, was staring at the audience the whole time, was able to crack a few jokes based on some unexpected things happening in the crowd, and made the whole crowd laugh.

Only if I could explain my happiness at that moment.

But oh, that, satisfaction ❤️

The whole crowd clapped at the end, appreciated the seminar, and came up with interesting questions as well. The confidence boost I got that day, the adrenaline rush ❤️‍🔥

Still gives me goosebumps when I think about it.

“But some clients don’t prefer working with companies. They’d rather hire someone independently than hire the company. That much transparency will get you killed” 

Heard this so many times and my answer has always been the same. We’d be happy to have less number of clients. That’s fine. The world will not end if we don’t have more revenue in the next month than the previous.

We are fine with slow growth if that’s the cost of being overly transparent. But I have hardly found that to be the case. The growth seems consistent, it’s scalable because we are not worried about hiding anything from the client, we don’t hide the leave of the employees or national holidays, if someone is sick, we call in sick on the client side, if it’s a public holiday, we don’t invoice for that day.

The reason some clients don’t prefer working with companies is because of this bad and very common practice of hiding things, hiding resources, over-selling skills, hiding mistakes, and false testimonials.

We work on new technologies all the time, but not using a fake testimonial, we show them what we have done and that we feel we are capable of doing this new thing as well. And it works all the time (doesn’t work 10-20% of the time)

We can transform the whole industry and change this mindset of the clients, the moment we all aim to deliver what we promise, show what we have, and be what we are. It works. That's howworks. We are a living example.

”Everything’s your fault”

Back in 2018, I watched a bit too many Gary Vaynerchuk videos (I still do) and this ☝🏼 is one of the things that totally changed my thought process.

The moment you consider yourself responsible for things happening in your life, you start looking for solutions to the problems instead of the person or reason to blame.

In my personal or professional life, I take 100% ownership, no questions asked.

- Someone mishandled a client? My mistake. I should have appointed the right person for the job.
- Someone took a good client of ours? My mistake, we weren’t able to build a relation, strong enough to retain the client.
- We are not able to deliver on-time? My mistake, I should have taught my team better about how to give better estimations.
- Our sales target were not met? My mistake. I should have been more in touch with the day-to-day of how sales were going
- Some critical person left the company? My mistake, I should have been in touch with them about their goals
- Someone messed up my mood? My mistake, I expected too much from them.

With this mindset, you start to look for solutions, you start to build processes, so you can avoid making such “mistakes” in the future.

The key to this thought process is not to blame yourself, but to consider yourself in control of things happening in your life. It creates a problem-solving mindset and you unknowingly start building a process that is immune to any outside negative influence.

Under-promise 📈 & Over-deliver 💹

This is one of our key principles at RipeSeed. One of our ground rules is to tell the clients right away about what we are experienced in and what’s going to be a new problem for us. I adopted this habit back in 2018 when one of my earliest clients approached and asked for a mobile app for private security companies in the US. That problem was very interesting to solve and I had the skills of App development, but I had virtually zero experience with AWS. So this is what I did:

Under Promise: Had a quick look at the documentation of the services that we’ll be using in the app and told the client that I don’t have any experience with it at all, but I have seen the docs and I think I can do it. The client trusted my word and honesty that I was transparent and awarded the project. I asked for a month to deliver the initial version.

Over Deliver: With the deadline of 1 month, I worked hard to learn everything needed fromside of things and delivered the whole functional app, ready to release in ~25 days. That strengthened the client’s trust in me and that client turned into one of my longest-term clients, whom I still work with to this date.

And this strategy has worked for us time and time again. Instead of the general practice of over-promising everything in sales, we do it in reverse fashion.

1. A client was impressed with our previous work for him and asked us to work on Chrome extensions. We told them it was out of our skillset but willing to do it. We outperformed the expectations and the client engaged 5 engineers from our team for his ongoing projects. Now browser plugin development is one of our highest in-demand expertise.

2. We started working on Generative AI back in December 2022 with 0 experience whatsoever and told the client right away. He trusted us, we delivered and now Generative AI is one of our most in-demand skillset and that client always spreads good word for us whenever we put him in referrals.

This strategy has helped us increase our area of expertise, by maintaining and improving our client relations as well. No good client wants to hear that you are a know-it-all person. Any real person or company cannot have everything under their portfolio. It makes absolute sense to admit what you don’t know, but being open to learning what you can. And if the client only wants someone who has worked on everything that his project needs, he probably isn’t going to prove a patient or a good client in the longer run anyway. So… best of luck 🙌

How much part does luck play in one's journey? A LOT!!! 
Then what can we do about it? Increase the chances of luck wherever you can!!! 

Whenever I tell someone about our journey or how we got some good clients, good team members, good connections, I cannot resist saying “But I think I got lucky”

And I truly mean it.

1. What if I was away watching a season or sleeping or away from my phone when that very good client who was critical for our survival reached out, and I couldn't respond to him right away? What if someone else responded him earlier and impressed him?

2. What if I got into some wrong group of people and went on a wrong career trajectory?

3. What if I underestimated a particular networking event and skipped that, the one from which I got some very good connections?

The answer to most of these what ifs is same. Increase your chances of luck. In sales, and especially in cold outreach, it's the game of numbers, more than quality. You can write a perfect proposal, but your prospect gets tired after reading 8 proposals and yours was 9th. You can dedicate 2 hours of your day reaching out to new clients, but someone else was dedicating 8 hours of their day and their probability is already 4x yours.

So even though you cannot control luck directly, you can control the probability of being lucky.

Meet more people, network more, and you only need 1 or 2 people who can prove an excellent connection for you.

Someone who doesn't network at all, has extremely little (if not 0) probability of meeting someone of value, as compared to someone who met 200 people in 10 networking events in a month.

Someone who sends 2 proposals a week has very little probability of hearing back from a client as compared to someone putting in the work of sending 100 proposals a week.

So even though you cannot control your luck, you can surely increase your chances of it. Best of luck!

I think people can't appreciate the correctness of this statement enough.

I started with Android development and learned the whole thing from "Android Programming: The(2nd edition)". That book taught me how to "build software" using the right practices, in a scalable manner, implementing the right design patterns, and a lot more.

Later on, when I started doing web, desktop, and backend development, I started using the same practices, folder structures, and patterns in everything. People used to be surprised seeing my code but that was the "norm" for me. It felt natural to me to code that way.

People should really consider mastering "software development" instead of just taking crash courses in web and mobile apps these days.

The Key-Man Problem 🔐

Ever heard of it? It is a phenomenon when a business or some operations are totally reliant on any one individual, his expertise, his connections and his skills. Remember when in Breaking Bad 🧪, Walter White 👨🏻‍🦲 said to Skyler in that famous “I am the one who knocks…” scene:

”Do you know what would happen if I suddenly decided to stop going into work? A business big enough that it could be listed on the NASDAQ goes belly up. Disappears! It ceases to exist without me.”

Walt was the Key Man. Is that a good thing? For your self-esteem, maybe, for your work-life balance, for a business to thrive, absolutely not.

In the early days of RipeSeed, I faced a similar situation. I was the key “Engineer”. Only I knew how to work on complex projects, how to set up CI/CD, or work on complex cloud workflows, but that’s the first thing that you solve in any software services business, right? You train your team and transfer the skills. So that’s what we did and I got out of that. But that was one of the many things we needed to solve.

What about sales? The heart of any business. I was doing all of the cold outreach, and I was stuck with it. I was doing the outreach via Upwork and we were doing near-stable revenue, but I had no idea about cold calling and email marketing and that’s when I talked to, I consider him my mentor. Most of what I do, is what I learnt working with(they are amazing, check them out). I asked him how do I scale the sales. And his advice was “Just delegate what you do to your team, don’t do anything new with the sales team, if you are doing upwork, ask your team to do Upwork as well” That was kind of a validation, and I started doing that. We started a sales team, we did some initial training and the team started generating leads which started converting to clients. One more problem solved.

Now I wasn’t doing the outreach, but I was still the one replying to the client whenever a lead responded. For quite some time, it continued on like this. Sales generated leads, and I did the interaction with the client. But I needed to remove myself from this part as well. So we started Client Success Team. A team of super-talented engineers, who’ll do the early interactions with the client, from their OWN account through the Agency (no shadowing, no imitating), whenever a lead responds. This took off.

The engineering 👨🏻‍💻 The sales 💰 The client success 🤝

Everything running without any reliance on any single person. I proudly say that some of our clients don’t even know my name. They know the CSM they are working with and the engineers involved in the project.

It’s critical to unlink yourself from the day-to-day of your business so you have the time and mental capacity to think how to scale. To do meetups, build longer-term connections, and invest your time in a longer-term play.

Building a crazy talented and responsible team 🧠 🚀

If you are a developer or a designer yourself, having any particular skills, it’s easier to get started with a services business, because you can sell exactly what you do. But then it’s harder to scale. To find the team to do what you think only YOU can do 🫵🏻

I had been working on Web (Frontend + Backend), Apps, and AWS for around 3-4 years, before I startedin mid-2021. When you are working individually for so long, it’s really hard to trust anyone with the code 💻 You think it’s only YOU, who can do this amazingly complex piece of feature. But you are SO wrong!!

The first guys I hired left within 2 weeks, my fault, because it was just me and him working side-by-side. He might have felt some pressure. I learned my lesson quickly and the next week, I hired 3 undergraduates. The criteria:

- It won’t be an internship, so the role & responsibilities wouldn’t be like an internship
- They must be skilled in full-stack development already, apart from being good programmers

So these 3 people joined the company, who are, I am so proud to say, still with us (thanks,,🙌). We had some projects going on at that moment, using, CloudFormation,,,, it was a complex SaaS application.

I trained them initially, and I was there with them if they faced any issues because I built that platform with my hands. The nerd inside me was afraid if they could do it or not, but they all surprised me. Now, one can say I got lucky with the team, and I would totally agree ✌🏻 but this has proved time and time again for me. You just have to trust your team with the complex tasks, be with them, guide them and they all can do it.

The criteria we defined for these first three hires, became the foundation of how we hire. So even when we started growing, the criteria remained:

- We won’t hire someone who we need to train on everything. We train on AWS or DevOps or improve their skills, but they have to bring something to the table, Mobile, Web, or Game Development
- They have to be open to learning new technologies
- We don’t have frontend-only or backend-only roles, we hire and maintain a full-stack team

This is how the engineering team offormed and stands to the strength of 28 people today ✊ The ground rules we defined were carried on by the team, which now interviews and hires on these basic principles.

How we built the sales team and how we streamlined the sales process is a whole different and very interesting story. Which I’ll cover in some other post. But I hope this answers the question that I get asked very often, How do you hire?

When starting something new, it’s really critical to stay laser-focused on what and why you want to do something. Is it going to be beneficial for your goal or is it going to just look and sound “cool”? I am glad we could avoid most of those things in our early days and till today as well. Some of those things are:

Cool Workspace 🏤 Having a cool office space with grass and wooden floors, paintings on the walls, play stations, and a nice book rack in your office, is something that'd really look amazing, but, how critical is that? Is the current look and feel too bad? Should we be channeling our energies into making the office look cool or should we invest that amount in our talent, in bonuses, and in experimentation? The answer was obvious.

The Product Trap 🪤 This is the most critical one I’d say. If you start with the mindset of being a client-service company and you start doing products to keep the team busy, you are doing injustice to the product and to yourself as well. The product mindset is totally different from the services mindset. Starting products will make you feel like the team is “occupied”, you’ll be doing “product planning meetings”, you’ll be focused on building a product while finding new clients alongside. You’ll feel like you are busy and doing something, but instead, that won’t be generating any value that's crucial to the survival of the company.

Entertainment 🏄🏽 We invest heavily into team satisfaction in forms of competitive packages, a nicer culture, good & and timely (timely is the important part) bonuses, and company-wide monthly dinners. But we never went on a company-wide trip for the whole first two years. The first time we went for one, was on the 2nd anniversary of the company. It’s critical to slowly raise the bar of your entertainment/fun standards, instead of just starting right from the top. This gives you and everyone the sense of validation as well, that we are making progress.

Becoming a US-based Company 🇺🇸 Now I won’t say you shouldn’t, but we never really considered registering ourselves outside of Pakistan as something of higher priority. Yes, the majority of our clients are from the US, but we tell them right away that we operate from Pakistan and we have a physical office space here. It never made sense to call ourselves a US-based company when you have never been there and the team is not operating from the US. We proudly work from Pakistan 🇵🇰 and our clients work with us for quality, trust, and transparency.

Now I won’t say that we will never do the things mentioned above. We will, for sure, as the need arises, but not focusing on them for the good two years helped us stay focused, generate more backup, scale the team by offering better incentives, and I always recommend everyone to do this.

In some future posts, I'll list the things we did in the early days that I think we could've avoided.

This picture is from October 2021, when RipeSeed made some initial hirings in the company and scaled from a team of 1 to 5. 

We had some ground rules, we defined some rights and wrongs of starting/running a company. The rule was to try and scale the business by doing things that "can scale". That can prove beneficial to everyone involved in the process. The rules were:

1. Brutal Honesty 🩸 We'll stay true to what we can do and what we can't. Even if we want to work on something new, we'll just tell the clients that we don't have the experience but we think we can do it. Clients were always impressed by it and most of the time agreed to it.

2. Quality of Team 💪 We hired the best talent, under-graduates, from the most prestigious IT universities, tried paying them above market for under-graduates at that time, and offered bonuses on top of them. So the ones who got engaged on client projects were financially growing along with the company as well.

3. Tech Stack 📲 From the very early days, we started training the team on, Web & Mobile development, CI/CD and started engaging them on real-life projects. AWS is not something every fresh grad or undergrad jumps into. But we were setting a higher bar for everyone and that defined a baseline of excellence in the team.

4. Client Transparency 🤝 No matter what, we'll provide the transparency of engineers involved in the projects. The client will be provided access to talk to the engineers directly. This proved to be beneficial to us in two ways. The clients were super impressed by the transparency and the team gained experience in client interaction in the very early days of their career.

5. Pay High, Charge High 🏦 We defined a base rate for our services, so no matter what happens, we never cross that threshold. We will always charge above that hourly rate. We will never market ourselves as the cheapest providers. We'll sell ourselves on our quality, our transparency, our honesty and our skills. This helped us maintain a higher-than-market or market-competitive package for our team and retain the team for a longer period of time.

6. Agency from Day 1 🏤 And boy was it hard to convince the clients to work with agencies!!! But the rule was to always tell them in the first meeting that it's an agency. For some, it was a no-go. But that was our red line. We never tried to acquire any client by presenting ourselves as individuals and hiding a team behind us.

I can write many more pointers but just don't wanna clutter the post. It's been over two years since this picture was captured, and I can proudly sayis still standing true to these rules.

RipeSeed Army is now 28 people strong ✊ 2 years old 🏆

On July 27th, 2023, RipeSeed turned 2 years old and to celebrate this achievement, we took a company-wide trip to northern areas 🏔 and Khanpur Dam 🌊 I remember our first anniversary, we had a team size of around 18 people. So we have definitely grown in headcount.

We achieved multiple goals in the last 6 months ⭐️

💵 We crossed our highest-ever monthly revenue
🏅 We became Expert-Vetted and crossed half a million USD in revenue on
🎯 We successfully and timely delivered bonuses and annual appraisal
🤝 Our team retention rate is extremely high, multiple team members completed 2 years of tenure and various team members got promoted in their roles
🧠 We now have our Sales Team and Client Success Team, working in sync, to regularly talk to new clients, deliver quality work, and maintain good relationships with existing ones, without dependency on any single individual
🤖 We rode thewave pretty soon enough, even before the ChatGPT-API was out, and for the past 6 months, we have completed various AI-based projects, and got one of our projects featured on

Proud to have this amazing bunch of people with me and I hope we achieve many more milestones for many years to come 🤜🏻🤛🏻

RipeSeed just crossed half a million USD in revenue on Upwork 🎉

Started in July 2021, I never imagined we'll be able to grow at such a rapid pace. We are now a team of over 25 people, each and everyone contributing significantly to where we are today.

Every initial stage company faces a lot of issues while trying to scale up. You are continuously hit by sudden revenue declines, client's ramping down, delivery challenges, and people management issues. Scaling from team of 1 to 4 then 4 to 6, to 10, to 15 to 20 and now over 25, each and every stage required us to unlock a specific set of challenges that we had to face along the way.

But I believe we got lucky in so many things as well. We are lucky to have such an exceptionally talented team that keeps coming up with ways to improve our technical strengths and deliver quality work. We are lucky to have been able to get new clients whenever we need them. There have been times when some crucial clients just disappeared or ramped down and it seemed like it's going to be hard, but something happened and new even better clients came up and we got back on our track. I consider that an absolute luck and some special sort of blessing upon us.

The goal has always been to be the "good ones". Both to our team and to our clients. We try to actually incentivize the ones who are contributing towards the success of the company instead of just giving them hope that they will be compensated for their contributions. We stay true to our clients by being transparent about our processes and our expertise. We believe in under-promising and over-delivering and apparently, it's been working out pretty well for us.

It has worked out better than I could ever imagine and fingers crossed for whatever is ahead of us.
